questions:
A 28-year-old man who has recently returned from Nigeria presents with a painful ulcer on his genitals. On examination, you note a 1cm x 1cm ulcerated lesion with a ragged border. You also note tender lymphadenopathy in the groin.

What is the most likely causative organism?
notes:
The painful genital ulcer with a ragged border associated with tender inguinal lymphadenopathy points to chancroid. Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

Herpes simplex virus also causes painful genital ulcers, but they are generally smaller and multiple and primary attacks are often associated with fever.

The other organisms are causes of painless genital ulcers: C. trachomatis causes lymphogranuloma venereum; T. pallidum causes syphilis; K. granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale.
question:
A 28-year-old man who has recently returned from Nigeria presents with a painful ulcer on his genitals. On examination, you note a 1cm x 1cm ulcerated lesion with a ragged border. You also note tender lymphadenopathy in the groin.

What is the most likely causative organism?
question_notes:
The painful genital ulcer with a ragged border associated with tender inguinal lymphadenopathy points to chancroid. Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi.

Herpes simplex virus also causes painful genital ulcers, but they are generally smaller and multiple and primary attacks are often associated with fever.

The other organisms are causes of painless genital ulcers: C. trachomatis causes lymphogranuloma venereum; T. pallidum causes syphilis; K. granulomatis causes granuloma inguinale.
title: Chancroid
body: Chancroid is a tropical disease caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. It causes painful genital ulcers associated with unilateral, painful inguinal lymph node enlargement. The ulcers typically have a sharply defined, ragged, undermined border.

questions:
A 7-year-old is referred to paediatric clinic by a GP as they are concerned about the presence of a murmur, heard incidentally. The patient is otherwise asymptomatic and well. After examination, the paediatrician is reassured and diagnoses a benign ejection systolic murmur.

Which of the following is a feature of a benign ejection systolic murmur?
notes: A benign ejection systolic murmur varies with posture. All other answers are features of pathological murmurs. 'Only mild symptoms' is not a good thing - any symptom at all is a sign that the murmur is not benign.
question:
A 7-year-old is referred to paediatric clinic by a GP as they are concerned about the presence of a murmur, heard incidentally. The patient is otherwise asymptomatic and well. After examination, the paediatrician is reassured and diagnoses a benign ejection systolic murmur.

Which of the following is a feature of a benign ejection systolic murmur?
question_notes: A benign ejection systolic murmur varies with posture. All other answers are features of pathological murmurs. 'Only mild symptoms' is not a good thing - any symptom at all is a sign that the murmur is not benign.
title: Innocent murmurs
body:
Innocent murmurs heard in children include

Ejection murmursDue to turbulent blood flow at the outflow tract of the heart
Venous humsDue to the turbulent blood flow in the great veins returning to the heart. Heard as a continuous blowing noise heard just below the clavicles
Still's murmurLow-pitched sound heard at the lower left sternal edge

Characteristics of an innocent ejection murmur include:
  • soft-blowing murmur in the pulmonary area or short buzzing murmur in the aortic area
  • may vary with posture
  • localised with no radiation
  • no diastolic component
  • no thrill
  • no added sounds (e.g. clicks)
  • asymptomatic child
  • no other abnormality
concept: A benign ejection murmur varies with posture
links:
Patient.info36
Heart Murmurs in Children
media:
Innocent Systolic Murmur - REQUIRES HEADPHONES
Thinklabs - YouTube00

questions:
A 72-year-old woman who takes bendroflumethiazide for hypertension is admitted to the Emergency Department. Admission bloods show the following:

Na+131 mmol/l
K+2.2 mmol/l
Urea3.1 mmol/l
Creatinine56 µmol/l
Glucose4.3 mmol/l

Which one of the following ECG features is most likely to be seen?
notes:
The correct answer is that U waves would be seen on the ECG. Hypokalaemia, which is present in this case (K+ 2.2 mmol/l), characteristically causes U waves to appear on the ECG. U waves are small positive deflections that follow the T wave and are best seen in leads V2 and V3. The patient's low potassium is likely due to thiazide diuretic therapy (bendroflumethiazide), which is a common cause of hypokalaemia. Other ECG changes associated with hypokalaemia include T wave flattening, ST segment depression, and prominent U waves.

Short PR interval is not correct as this is typically associated with pre-excitation syndromes such as Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, rather than electrolyte disturbances. A normal PR interval is 120-200ms.

Short QT interval is incorrect. While electrolyte disturbances can affect the QT interval, hypokalaemia typically causes QT interval prolongation rather than shortening. Short QT interval is seen in hypercalcaemia.

Delta waves are also incorrect. Delta waves are a feature of Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome, where there is pre-excitation of the ventricles via an accessory pathway. They are not associated with electrolyte disturbances.

J waves are incorrect. J waves (or Osborn waves) are typically seen in hypothermia or hypercalcaemia, appearing as a positive deflection at the J point (the junction between the QRS complex and ST segment). They are not a feature of hypokalaemia.

title: ECG: hypokalaemia
body:
ECG features of hypokalaemia
  • U waves
  • small or absent T waves (occasionally inversion)
  • prolong PR interval
  • ST depression
  • long QT


In Hypokalaemia, U have no Pot and no T, but a long PR and a long QT
links:
Life in the Fast Lane5811
ECG: Hypokalaemia changes

options: Folic acid 400 micrograms once a day from now to 12 weeks of pregnancy
Folic acid 400 micrograms once a day from now to the end of pregnancy
Folic acid 5 mg once a day from now to 12 weeks of pregnancy
Folic acid 5 mg once a day from now to the end of pregnancy
Folic acid 1 mg once a day from now to 12 weeks of pregnancy
questions:
A 30-year-old woman presents to the GP surgery for the pre-conceptual counselling. She would like to get pregnant within the next 3 months. She is nulliparous and past medical history includes Type 1 diabetes mellitus and irritable bowel syndrome. She is only taking insulin and has no known drug allergy. Her BMI is 23 kg/m2. She does not drink and does not smoke. She has no family history of neural tube defects and her partner has no history of neural tube defects.

What is the dose regime of folic acid she should be taking?
notes:
She has Type1 diabetes mellitus. Women with diabetes are considered at high risk of conceiving a child with neural tube defects. She should be taking folic acid 5mg once a day 3 months before conception to 12 weeks of pregnancy.

Other options are either incorrect dosage for her or incorrect length of the regime.
question:
A 30-year-old woman presents to the GP surgery for the pre-conceptual counselling. She would like to get pregnant within the next 3 months. She is nulliparous and past medical history includes Type 1 diabetes mellitus and irritable bowel syndrome. She is only taking insulin and has no known drug allergy. Her BMI is 23 kg/m2. She does not drink and does not smoke. She has no family history of neural tube defects and her partner has no history of neural tube defects.

What is the dose regime of folic acid she should be taking?
question_notes:
She has Type1 diabetes mellitus. Women with diabetes are considered at high risk of conceiving a child with neural tube defects. She should be taking folic acid 5mg once a day 3 months before conception to 12 weeks of pregnancy.

Other options are either incorrect dosage for her or incorrect length of the regime.
title: Folic acid
body:
Folic acid is converted to tetrahydrofolate (THF). Green, leafy vegetables are a good source of folic acid.

Functions
  • THF plays a key role in the transfer of 1-carbon units (e.g. methyl, methylene, and formyl groups) to the essential substrates involved in the synthesis of DNA & RNA

Causes of folic acid deficiency:
  • phenytoin
  • methotrexate
  • pregnancy
  • alcohol excess

Consequences of folic acid deficiency:
  • macrocytic, megaloblastic anaemia
  • neural tube defects

Prevention of neural tube defects (NTD) during pregnancy:
  • all women should take 400mcg of folic acid until the 12th week of pregnancy
  • women at higher risk of conceiving a child with a NTD should take 5mg of folic acid from before conception until the 12th week of pregnancy
  • women are considered higher risk if any of the following apply:
    • either partner has a NTD, they have had a previous pregnancy affected by a NTD, or they have a family history of a NTD
    • the woman is taking antiepileptic drugs or has coeliac disease, diabetes, or thalassaemia trait.
    • the woman is obese (defined as a body mass index [BMI] of 30 kg/m2 or more).
concept: Women with diabetes are considered at high risk of conceiving a child with neural tube defects
media:
Folate deficiency
Osmosis - YouTube22
 
Megaloblastic Anemia - Folic Acid Deficiency
PhysioPathoPharmaco - YouTube33

2857.concept_text: Phenytoin is a cause of folic acid deficiency

3057.concept_text: Women with BMI of 30 kg/m2 or more are considered at high risk of conceiving a child with neural tube defects

3060.concept_text: Women on antiepileptics, who try to conceive, should receive folic acid 5mg instead of 400mcg OD

3062.concept_text: Women with diabetes are considered at high risk of conceiving a child with neural tube defects

3574.concept_text: Pregnant obese women (BMI >30 kg/m2), should be given high dose 5mg folic acid

7260.concept_text: In women at risk of neural tube defects, folic acid should be started before conception

questions:
A 19-year-old woman is rushed into the emergency department after having a reaction to her dinner at a Thai restaurant that may have contained peanuts. She used her adrenaline autoinjector at the time of the onset of the reaction and was given a further dose of intramuscular adrenaline by the ambulance crew.

On examination, she has a temperature of 37.5ºC with a heart rate of 134 beats/min and a blood pressure of 90/52mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 28 breaths/min with oxygen saturations of 94% on air.

What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
notes:
Intravenous adrenaline infusion is correct. This patient has clinical features of refractory anaphylaxis (e.g. tachycardia, tachypnoea and hypotension) that have not responded to the initial management of intramuscular adrenaline. The Resuscitation Council recommends that, following the administration of 2 doses of intramuscular adrenaline, if symptoms of anaphylaxis are not improving, an adrenaline infusion should be started.

Further intramuscular adrenaline is incorrect. This patient has already received 2 doses of intramuscular adrenaline. According to the anaphylaxis guidelines, this patient should now be started on an adrenaline infusion.

Intravenous chlorphenamine is incorrect. The updated guidelines on the management of anaphylaxis have removed the use of intravenous chlorphenamine from the algorithm.

Intravenous hydrocortisone is incorrect. The updated guidelines on the management of anaphylaxis have removed the use of intravenous hydrocortisone from the algorithm.

Salbutamol nebuliser is incorrect. Adrenaline nebulisers can be used as an adjunct in the management of anaphylaxis. However, salbutamol nebulisers do not play a role.
question:
A 19-year-old woman is rushed into the emergency department after having a reaction to her dinner at a Thai restaurant that may have contained peanuts. She used her adrenaline autoinjector at the time of the onset of the reaction and was given a further dose of intramuscular adrenaline by the ambulance crew.

On examination, she has a temperature of 37.5ºC with a heart rate of 134 beats/min and a blood pressure of 90/52mmHg. Her respiratory rate is 28 breaths/min with oxygen saturations of 94% on air.

What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
question_notes:
Intravenous adrenaline infusion is correct. This patient has clinical features of refractory anaphylaxis (e.g. tachycardia, tachypnoea and hypotension) that have not responded to the initial management of intramuscular adrenaline. The Resuscitation Council recommends that, following the administration of 2 doses of intramuscular adrenaline, if symptoms of anaphylaxis are not improving, an adrenaline infusion should be started.

Further intramuscular adrenaline is incorrect. This patient has already received 2 doses of intramuscular adrenaline. According to the anaphylaxis guidelines, this patient should now be started on an adrenaline infusion.

Intravenous chlorphenamine is incorrect. The updated guidelines on the management of anaphylaxis have removed the use of intravenous chlorphenamine from the algorithm.

Intravenous hydrocortisone is incorrect. The updated guidelines on the management of anaphylaxis have removed the use of intravenous hydrocortisone from the algorithm.

Salbutamol nebuliser is incorrect. Adrenaline nebulisers can be used as an adjunct in the management of anaphylaxis. However, salbutamol nebulisers do not play a role.
title: Anaphylaxis
body:
Anaphylaxis may be defined as a severe, life-threatening, generalised or systemic hypersensitivity reaction.

Common identified causes of anaphylaxis:
  • food (e.g. nuts) - the most common cause in children
  • drugs
  • venom (e.g. wasp sting)

Features

The Resus Council UK define anaphylaxis as:
  • the sudden onset and rapid progression of symptoms
  • Airway and/or Breathing and/or Circulation problems
  • Airway problems may include:
    • swelling of the throat and tongue →hoarse voice and stridor
  • Breathing problems may include:
    • respiratory wheeze
    • dyspnoea
  • Circulation problems may include:
    • hypotension
    • tachycardia

This means that if there are no ABC problems then the patient is technically not having anaphylaxis.

Around 80-90% of patients also have skin and mucosal changes:
  • generalised pruritus
  • widespread erythematous or urticarial rash

Management

Anaphylaxis is one of the few times when you would not have time to look up the dose of a medication. The Resuscitation Council guidelines on anaphylaxis have recently been updated. Intramuscular adrenaline is by far the most important drug in anaphylaxis and should be given as soon as possible. Previously IV hydrocortisone was also recommended but the evidence base for this was poor and it was removed in the 2021 update.

The recommended doses for adrenaline are as follows: BNF

AgeAdrenaline dose
< 6 months100 - 150 micrograms (0.1 - 0.15 ml 1 in 1,000)
6 months - 6 years150 micrograms (0.15 ml 1 in 1,000)
6-12 years300 micrograms (0.3ml 1 in 1,000)
Adult and child > 12 years500 micrograms (0.5ml 1 in 1,000)

Adrenaline can be repeated every 5 minutes if necessary. The best site for IM injection is the anterolateral aspect of the middle third of the thigh.

Refractory anaphylaxis
  • defined as respiratory and/or cardiovascular problems persist despite 2 doses of IM adrenaline
  • IV fluids should be given for shock
  • expert help should be sought for consideration of an IV adrenaline infusion


Management following stabilisation:
  • non-sedating oral antihistamines, in preference to chlorphenamine, may be given following initial stabilisation especially in patients with persisting skin symptoms (urticaria and/or angioedema)
  • sometimes it can be difficult to establish whether a patient had a true episode of anaphylaxis. Serum tryptase levels are sometimes taken in such patients as they remain elevated for up to 12 hours following an acute episode of anaphylaxis
  • all patients with a new diagnosis of anaphylaxis should be referred to a specialist allergy clinic
  • an adrenaline injector should be givens an interim measure before the specialist allergy assessment (unless the reaction was drug-induced)
    • patients should be prescribed 2 adrenaline auto-injectors
    • training should be provided on how to use it
  • a risk-stratified approach to discharge should be taken as biphasic reactions can occur in up to 20% of patients

The Resus Council UK recommend the following risk-stratified approach to discharge:
  • fast-track discharge (after 2 hours of symptom resolution):
    • good response to a single dose of adrenaline
    • complete resolution of symptoms
    • has been given an adrenaline auto-injector and trained how to use it
    • adequate supervision following discharge
  • minimum 6 hours after symptom resolution
    • 2 doses of IM adrenaline needed, or
    • previous biphasic reaction
  • minimum 12 hours after symptom resolution
    • severe reaction requiring > 2 doses of IM adrenaline
    • patient has severe asthma
    • possibility of an ongoing reaction (e.g. slow-release medication)
    • patient presents late at night
    • patient in areas where access to emergency access care may be difficult
    • observation for at 12 hours following symptom resolution
concept: Refractory anaphylaxis is defined as respiratory and/or cardiovascular problems persisting despite 2 doses of IM adrenaline
links:
BNF1812
Medical emergencies in the community


Resus Council277
Anaphylaxis guidelines
media:
Type I Hypersensitivity

Type I hypersensitivity
Osmosis - YouTube13

423.concept_text: Anaphylaxis - serum tryptase levels rise following an acute episode

424.concept_text: Anaphylaxis - adult adrenaline dose = 500 mcg (0.5 ml of 1 in 1,000)

1696.concept_text: Anaphylaxis: A child aged 6-11 years should be administered adrenaline at a dose of 300 micrograms (0.3ml), repeated every 5 minutes if necessary

2374.concept_text: IM adrenaline is the single most important drug in anaphylaxis. Hydrocortisone/chlorphenamine are no longer given

2648.concept_text: A risk-stratified approach should be taken when discharging patients who have presented with anaphylaxis

4666.concept_text: In the treatment of anaphylaxis, you can repeat adrenaline every 5 minutes

8666.concept_text: < 6 months adrenaline dose for anaphylaxis 100 - 150 mcg (0.1 - 0.15ml 1 in 1,000)

8667.concept_text: 6 months - 6 years adrenaline dose for anaphylaxis 150 mcg (0.15ml 1 in 1,000)

11458.concept_text: Refractory anaphylaxis is defined as respiratory and/or cardiovascular problems persisting despite 2 doses of IM adrenaline

11459.concept_text: IV adrenaline (under expert guidance) + IV fluid bolus are used for the management of refractory anaphylaxis

11460.concept_text:
IM adrenaline should be injected in the anterolateral aspect of the
middle third of the thigh

11461.concept_text: The Resus Council UK define anaphylaxis as: - the sudden onset and rapid progression of symptoms - Airway and/or Breathing and/or Circulation problems

questions:
A 73-year-old man attends his GP due to worsening vision. He reports a gradual appearance of dark floaters across his vision for several months and more recently has had some episodes of flashing lights when outdoors in bright sunshine. His only past medical history is hypertension for which he takes 5mg ramipril daily. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history, abstains from alcohol, and is independent for his activities of daily living.

What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's change in vision?
notes:
This patient is presenting with flashers and floaters which are associated with vitreous detachment. Typically, these are noted in the peripheral visual field. This diagnosis is associated with hypertension and diabetes mellitus in older patients. Retinal detachment can occur following vitreous detachment and is typically referred to in questions as a 'dense shadow' that progresses from the peripheral towards central vision, appearing as a veil or curtain.

Central retinal artery occlusion is associated with atherosclerotic thromboembolisms or temporal arteritis. Patients will present with acute, monocular, painless loss of vision. Examination findings will show an afferent pupillary defect and a cherry-red spot on the retina. This patient has not had a complete loss of vision, therefore this is not the most likely diagnosis.

Ischaemic optic neuropathy can occur due to heavy tobacco smoking and is most common in patients over 70 years of age. However, as patients present with monocular, acute, painless vision loss - this is not the most likely diagnosis. Examination will show a relative afferent pupillary defect and a pale, swollen optic disc, cotton wool spots and peripapillary haemorrhages.

Macular degeneration is the most common cause of blindness in the UK. Patients will report distortion in vision (straight lines appearing curved), blurred vision, and central vision is affected first (unlike vitreous detachment which tends to affect the peripheries first). In dry macular degeneration, there will be drusen seen on fundoscopy.

Temporal arteritis usually has a more rapid onset than this vignette demonstrates and is associated with headache and jaw claudication. Symptoms of vision disturbance (reduced visual acuity) usually occur within a few weeks and are associated with tenderness over the temporal artery region.
question:

He reports a gradual appearance of dark floaters across his vision for several months and more recently has had some episodes of flashing lights when outdoors in bright sunshine. He has a 40 pack-year smoking history, abstains from alcohol, and is independent for his activities of daily living.

What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's change in vision?

Temporal arteritis usually has a more rapid onset than this vignette demonstrates and is associated with headache and jaw claudication. Symptoms of vision disturbance (reduced visual acuity) usually occur within a few weeks and are associated with tenderness over the temporal artery region.
title: Sudden loss of vision
body:
Sudden loss is a frightening symptom for patients. It may represent an ongoing issue or only be temporary. The term transient monocular visual loss (TMVL) describes a sudden, transient loss of vision that lasts less than 24 hours.

The most common causes of a sudden painless loss of vision are as follows:
  • ischaemic/vascular (e.g. thrombosis, embolism, temporal arteritis etc). This includes recognised syndromes e.g. occlusion of central retinal vein and occlusion of central retinal artery
  • vitreous haemorrhage
  • retinal detachment
  • retinal migraine

Ischaemic/vascular
  • often referred to as 'amaurosis fugax'
  • wide differential including large artery disease (atherothrombosis, embolus, dissection), small artery occlusive disease (anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, vasculitis e.g. temporal arteritis), venous disease and hypoperfusion
  • may represent a form of transient ischaemic attack (TIA). It should therefore be treated in a similar fashion, with aspirin 300mg being given
  • altitudinal field defects are often seen: 'curtain coming down'
  • ischaemic optic neuropathy is due to occlusion of the short posterior ciliary arteries, causing damage to the optic nerve

Central retinal vein occlusion
  • incidence increases with age, more common than arterial occlusion
  • causes: glaucoma, polycythaemia, hypertension
  • severe retinal haemorrhages are usually seen on fundoscopy

Central retinal artery occlusion
  • due to thromboembolism (from atherosclerosis) or arteritis (e.g. temporal arteritis)
  • features include afferent pupillary defect, 'cherry red' spot on a pale retina

Vitreous haemorrhage
  • causes: diabetes, bleeding disorders, anticoagulants
  • features may include sudden visual loss, dark spots

Retinal detachment
  • features of vitreous detachment, which may precede retinal detachment, include flashes of light or floaters (see below)

Differentiating posterior vitreous detachment, retinal detachment and vitreous haemorrhage

Posterior vitreous detachmentRetinal detachmentVitreous haemorrhage
Flashes of light (photopsia) - in the peripheral field of vision
Floaters, often on the temporal side of the central vision		Dense shadow that starts peripherally progresses towards the central vision
A veil or curtain over the field of vision
Straight lines appear curved
Central visual loss		Large bleeds cause sudden visual loss
Moderate bleeds may be described as numerous dark spots
Small bleeds may cause floaters
links:
The Royal Australian College of General Practitioners2038
Sudden loss of vision review


American Academy of Ophthalmology1114
Central Retinal Artery Occlusion


Patient.info1413
Retinal artery occlusions


American Academy of Ophthalmology1311
Central Retinal Vein Occlusion

682.concept_text: Central retinal vein occlusion - sudden painless loss of vision, severe retinal haemorrhages on fundoscopy

1619.concept_text: Central retinal artery occlusion - sudden painless loss of vision, cherry red spot on fundus

4855.concept_text: Retinal detachment is a cause of sudden painless loss of vision. It is characterised by a dense shadow starting peripherally and progressing centrally

4856.concept_text: Vitreous haemorrhage is a cause of sudden painless loss of vision in the context of diabetic retinopathy

questions:
A 33-year-old woman presents to her general practitioner with several days of vaginal discharge. She describes the smell as 'fishy' and that the discharge is thin and white. She denies any other symptoms and has no significant past medical history. The patient takes no regular medications. A vaginal swab is taken and sent for testing and microscopy:

Vaginal pH4.8
MicroscopyStippled appearance of vaginal epithelial cells

Given the probable diagnosis, what is the most likely causative organism?
notes:
The correct answer is Gardnerella vaginalis. This patient's presentation is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis (BV). This is an incredibly common condition characterised by the overgrowth of otherwise commensal bacteria. The most common culprit is the overgrowth of Gardnerella vaginalis. It can be picked up incidentally as half of patients are asymptomatic, or patients may present with thin, white, malodorous discharge as seen here. Amsel's criteria are often used to diagnose BV, with three of the following four criteria needing to be true: thin grey/white discharge, 'fishy' odour upon adding 10% potassium hydroxide, high pH (> 4.5) and identification of epithelial cells with a stippled appearance (clue cells). Treatment involves the use of metronidazole.

Candida albicans is incorrect. This is the most common fungal species that causes vulvovaginal candidiasis. This would instead present with thick, 'cottage cheese-like' discharge and itching.

Chlamydia trachomatis is incorrect. This is a common sexually transmitted infection (STI) that may be detected asymptomatically or may present with cervicitis, intermenstrual bleeding and pelvic pain. The presentation here is more suggestive of BV.

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is incorrect. This is an STI and may be asymptomatic, or may present with fever and abdominopelvic pain. The history here is more suggestive of BV.

Trichomonas vaginalis is incorrect. Infection with this protozoan typically leads to a frothy, yellow-green discharge, rather than a thin, white discharge. Patients often also present with vulvovaginitis and a strawberry cervix may be seen on examination. Management, however, also involves the use of metronidazole.

title: Bacterial vaginosis
body:
Bacterial vaginosis (BV) describes an overgrowth of predominately anaerobic organisms such as Gardnerella vaginalis. This leads to a consequent fall in lactic acid producing aerobic lactobacilli resulting in a raised vaginal pH.

Whilst BV is not a sexually transmitted infection it is seen almost exclusively in sexually active women.

Features
  • vaginal discharge: 'fishy', offensive
  • asymptomatic in 50%

Amsel's criteria for diagnosis of BV - 3 of the following 4 points should be present
  • thin, white homogenous discharge
  • clue cells on microscopy: stippled vaginal epithelial cells
  • vaginal pH > 4.5
  • positive whiff test (addition of potassium hydroxide results in fishy odour)

Management
  • if the woman is asymptomatic, treatment is not usually required #link33
    • e.g. picked up on a swab done for different reasons
    • exceptions include if a woman is undergoing a termination of pregnancy
  • if symptomatic: oral metronidazole for 5-7 days #link34
    • 70-80% initial cure rate
    • relapse rate > 50% within 3 months
    • a single oral dose of metronidazole 2g may be used if adherence may be an issue
    • the BNF suggests topical metronidazole or topical clindamycin as alternatives
  • if pregnant #link32
    • results in an increased risk of preterm labour, low birth weight and chorioamnionitis, late miscarriage
    • it was previously taught that oral metronidazole should be avoided in the first trimester and topical clindamycin used instead. Recent guidelines however recommend that oral metronidazole is used throughout pregnancy
    • if asymptomatic: discuss with the woman's obstetrician if treatment is indicated
    • if symptomatic: either oral metronidazole for 5-7 days or topical treatment. The higher, stat dose of metronidazole mentioned above is not recommended

Comparison of bacterial vaginosis and Trichomonas vaginalis

© Image used on license from PathoPic
Clue cells - epithelial cells develop a stippled appearance due to being covered with bacteria
concept: Bacterial vaginosis - overgrowth of predominately Gardnerella vaginalis

questions: A 34-year-old man develops gross facial and tongue swelling shortly after being given the Japanese encephalitis vaccination. He is immediately given intramuscular adrenaline 500mcg. An ambulance is called, high-flow oxygen is applied and he is layed flat on the floor with his legs raised. Despite the adrenaline he facial swelling does not improve and his blood pressure is 82/54 mmHg. How soon after the first-dose of adrenaline can he be given a further dose?
notes:
The correct answer is 5 minutes. In the case of anaphylaxis, the UK Resuscitation Council guidelines recommend that a further dose of intramuscular adrenaline can be given if there is no improvement in symptoms within 5 minutes after the initial dose. This is because adrenaline has a rapid onset of action, and if no improvement is seen within this timeframe, it may be necessary to repeat the dose to ensure adequate treatment.

The first incorrect answer is 3 minutes. While adrenaline does have a rapid onset of action, waiting for at least 5 minutes allows enough time to assess the patient's response to the initial dose. Administering another dose too soon may result in excessive dosing and potential side effects such as tachycardia or hypertension.

The second incorrect answer is 10 minutes. Waiting for 10 minutes before administering another dose of adrenaline could potentially delay life-saving treatment for the patient. Anaphylaxis can progress rapidly, and it is crucial to treat promptly in order to prevent severe complications such as hypotension, airway obstruction or cardiac arrest.

The third incorrect answer is 15 minutes. Similar to waiting for 10 minutes, waiting for 15 minutes would also risk delaying essential treatment for anaphylaxis. The UK Resuscitation Council guidelines emphasize prompt administration of intramuscular adrenaline every 5 minutes until clinical improvement occurs.

Finally, the fourth incorrect answer is 30 minutes. Waiting for half an hour before administering another dose of adrenaline would put the patient at significant risk due to delayed treatment. In cases where anaphylactic symptoms do not improve or worsen after repeated doses of adrenaline, additional treatments such as intravenous fluids and antihistamines should be considered alongside early expert help from senior clinicians or specialists in allergy or intensive care medicine.

title: Anaphylaxis
body:
Anaphylaxis may be defined as a severe, life-threatening, generalised or systemic hypersensitivity reaction.

Common identified causes of anaphylaxis:
  • food (e.g. nuts) - the most common cause in children
  • drugs
  • venom (e.g. wasp sting)

Features

The Resus Council UK define anaphylaxis as:
  • the sudden onset and rapid progression of symptoms
  • Airway and/or Breathing and/or Circulation problems
  • Airway problems may include:
    • swelling of the throat and tongue →hoarse voice and stridor
  • Breathing problems may include:
    • respiratory wheeze
    • dyspnoea
  • Circulation problems may include:
    • hypotension
    • tachycardia

This means that if there are no ABC problems then the patient is technically not having anaphylaxis.

Around 80-90% of patients also have skin and mucosal changes:
  • generalised pruritus
  • widespread erythematous or urticarial rash

Management

Anaphylaxis is one of the few times when you would not have time to look up the dose of a medication. The Resuscitation Council guidelines on anaphylaxis have recently been updated. Intramuscular adrenaline is by far the most important drug in anaphylaxis and should be given as soon as possible. Previously IV hydrocortisone was also recommended but the evidence base for this was poor and it was removed in the 2021 update.

The recommended doses for adrenaline are as follows: BNF

AgeAdrenaline dose
< 6 months100 - 150 micrograms (0.1 - 0.15 ml 1 in 1,000)
6 months - 6 years150 micrograms (0.15 ml 1 in 1,000)
6-12 years300 micrograms (0.3ml 1 in 1,000)
Adult and child > 12 years500 micrograms (0.5ml 1 in 1,000)

Adrenaline can be repeated every 5 minutes if necessary. The best site for IM injection is the anterolateral aspect of the middle third of the thigh.

Refractory anaphylaxis
  • defined as respiratory and/or cardiovascular problems persist despite 2 doses of IM adrenaline
  • IV fluids should be given for shock
  • expert help should be sought for consideration of an IV adrenaline infusion


Management following stabilisation:
  • non-sedating oral antihistamines, in preference to chlorphenamine, may be given following initial stabilisation especially in patients with persisting skin symptoms (urticaria and/or angioedema)
  • sometimes it can be difficult to establish whether a patient had a true episode of anaphylaxis. Serum tryptase levels are sometimes taken in such patients as they remain elevated for up to 12 hours following an acute episode of anaphylaxis
  • all patients with a new diagnosis of anaphylaxis should be referred to a specialist allergy clinic
  • an adrenaline injector should be givens an interim measure before the specialist allergy assessment (unless the reaction was drug-induced)
    • patients should be prescribed 2 adrenaline auto-injectors
    • training should be provided on how to use it
  • a risk-stratified approach to discharge should be taken as biphasic reactions can occur in up to 20% of patients

The Resus Council UK recommend the following risk-stratified approach to discharge:
  • fast-track discharge (after 2 hours of symptom resolution):
    • good response to a single dose of adrenaline
    • complete resolution of symptoms
    • has been given an adrenaline auto-injector and trained how to use it
    • adequate supervision following discharge
  • minimum 6 hours after symptom resolution
    • 2 doses of IM adrenaline needed, or
    • previous biphasic reaction
  • minimum 12 hours after symptom resolution
    • severe reaction requiring > 2 doses of IM adrenaline
    • patient has severe asthma
    • possibility of an ongoing reaction (e.g. slow-release medication)
    • patient presents late at night
    • patient in areas where access to emergency access care may be difficult
    • observation for at 12 hours following symptom resolution
concept: In the treatment of anaphylaxis, you can repeat adrenaline every 5 minutes

questions: Which one of the following investigations is essential prior to starting anti-tuberculosis therapy?
notes: The British Thoracic Society have published guidelines on the management of tuberculosis. Liver functions tests should be checked in all cases and monitored throughout treatment. Visual acuity and renal function should also be checked prior to starting ethambutol
question: Which one of the following investigations is essential prior to starting anti-tuberculosis therapy?
question_notes: The British Thoracic Society have published guidelines on the management of tuberculosis. Liver functions tests should be checked in all cases and monitored throughout treatment. Visual acuity and renal function should also be checked prior to starting ethambutol
title: Tuberculosis: drug side-effects and mechanism of action
body:
Rifampicin
  • mechanism of action: inhibits bacterial DNA dependent RNA polymerase preventing transcription of DNA into mRNA
  • potent liver enzyme inducer
  • hepatitis, orange secretions
  • flu-like symptoms

Isoniazid
  • mechanism of action: inhibits mycolic acid synthesis
  • peripheral neuropathy: prevent with pyridoxine (Vitamin B6)
  • hepatitis, agranulocytosis
  • liver enzyme inhibitor

Pyrazinamide
  • mechanism of action:
    • converted by pyrazinamidase into pyrazinoic acid which in turn inhibits fatty acid synthase (FAS) I
    • this disrupts fatty acid production needed for bacterial growth
  • hyperuricaemia causing gout
  • arthralgia, myalgia
  • hepatitis

Ethambutol
  • mechanism of action: inhibits the enzyme arabinosyl transferase which polymerizes arabinose into arabinan
  • optic neuritis: check visual acuity before and during treatment
  • dose needs adjusting in patients with renal impairment
links:
NICE104
2016 Tuberculosis guidelines
media:
Tuberculosis

2654.concept_text: The risk of peripheral neuropathy with isoniazid can be reduced by prescribing pyridoxine

questions: A patient is brought to the Emergency Department in cardiac arrest. The monitor shows that he is in ventricular fibrillation. The paramedics have already given three cycles of cardiopulmonary resuscitation and intravenous adrenaline. You decide to give amiodarone. What is the correct dose of amiodarone to give initially?
notes:
The correct answer is 300 mg. In a patient with ventricular fibrillation who has already received three cycles of cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and intravenous adrenaline, the UK Resuscitation Council guidelines recommend administering an initial dose of 300 mg amiodarone. This antiarrhythmic drug works to restore normal heart rhythm by prolonging the action potential duration and refractory period, as well as slowing down the heart rate.

The other options provided are incorrect for the following reasons:

1 mg is too low a dose to have any significant effect on the patient's heart rhythm. Amiodarone needs to be administered at an appropriate dosage to effectively treat ventricular fibrillation and potentially save the patient's life.

10 mg is still not sufficient to achieve the desired therapeutic effect in this emergency situation. A higher dose of amiodarone is required in order to successfully manage ventricular fibrillation during cardiac arrest.

100 mg, although closer to the correct dosage, is still not adequate for managing this life-threatening arrhythmia. The UK Resuscitation Council guidelines specifically recommend a 300 mg initial dose in this scenario.

200 mg, while closer than some of the other options, is also not in line with current UK guidelines for treating ventricular fibrillation during cardiac arrest. Administering 300 mg of amiodarone provides the best chance of restoring normal heart function and improving patient outcomes in this critical situation.

200 mg, while closer than some of the other options, is also not in line with current UK guidelines for treating ventricular fibrillation during cardiac arrest. Administering 300 mg of amiodarone provides the best chance of restoring normal heart function and improving patient outcomes in this critical situation.
title: Adult advanced life support
body:
The following is based on the 2021 Resus Council guidelines. Please see the link for more details, below is only a very brief summary of key points.

It should be remembered that the algorithm divides patients into those with:
  • 'shockable' rhythms: ventricular fibrillation/pulseless ventricular tachycardia (VF/pulseless VT)
  • 'non-shockable' rhythms: asystole/pulseless-electrical activity (asystole/PEA)

Major points include:
  • chest compressions
    • the ratio of chest compressions to ventilation is 30:2
    • chest compressions are now continued while a defibrillator is charged
  • defibrillation
    • a single shock for VF/pulseless VT followed by 2 minutes of CPR
  • drug delivery
    • IV access should be attempted and is first-line
    • if IV access cannot be achieved then drugs should be given via the intraosseous route (IO)
    • delivery of drugs via a tracheal tube is no longer recommended
  • adrenaline
    • adrenaline 1 mg as soon as possible for non-shockable rhythms
    • during a VF/VT cardiac arrest, adrenaline 1 mg is given once chest compressions have restarted after the third shock
    • repeat adrenaline 1mg every 3-5 minutes whilst ALS continues
  • amiodarone
    • amiodarone 300 mg should be given to patients who are in VF/pulseless VT after 3 shocks have been administered.
    • a further dose of amiodarone 150 mg should be given to patients who are in VF/pulseless VT after 5 shocks have been administered
    • lidocaine used as an alternative if amiodarone is not available or a local decision has been made to use lidocaine instead
  • thrombolytic drugs
    • should be considered if a pulmonary embolus is suspected
    • if given, CPR should be continued for an extended period of 60-90 minutes


Other points
  • atropine is no longer recommended for routine use in asystole or pulseless electrical activity (PEA)
  • following successful resuscitation oxygen should be titrated to achieve saturations of 94-98%. This is to address the potential harm caused by hyperoxaemia

Reversible causes of cardiac arrest:

The 'Hs'The 'Ts'
  • Hypoxia
  • Hypovolaemia
  • Hyperkalaemia, hypokalaemia, hypoglycaemia, hypocalcaemia, acidaemia and other metabolic disorders
  • Hypothermia
  • Thrombosis (coronary or pulmonary)
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Tamponade - cardiac
  • Toxins
links:
Resuscitation Council6735
2021 Advanced Life Support guidelines


Resuscitation Council4222
2021 Basic Life Support guidelines

8608.concept_text: ALS - give adrenaline in non-shockable rhythm as soon as possible

9130.concept_text: VF/pulseless VT should be treated with 1 shock as soon as identified

11515.concept_text: In ALS, if IV access cannot be achieved then drugs should be given via the intraosseous route (IO) - the tracheal route is no longer recommended

11516.concept_text: In ALS, the ratio of chest compressions to ventilation is 30:2

11517.concept_text: In ALS, once adrenaline has been initially given it should be repeated every 3-5 minutes whilst ALS continues

11518.concept_text: In ALS, amiodarone 300 mg should be given to patients who are in VF/pulseless VT after 3 shocks have been administered.

11519.concept_text: In ALS, a further dose of amiodarone 150 mg should be given to patients who are in VF/pulseless VT after 5 shocks have been administered

11521.concept_text: Thrombolytic drugs should be considered during CPR if a PE is suspected
